awd_titl_txt: Planning Grant: Engineering Research Center for Lignin Engineering, Analysis, and Research for Sustainable Technology (CLEAReST)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Planning Grants for Engineering Research Centers competition was run as a pilot solicitation within the ERC program. Planning grants are not required as part of the full ERC competition, but intended to build capacity among teams to plan for convergent, center-scale engineering research.

The objective of this planning grant is to move towards a NSF-sponsored Center for Lignin Engineering, Analysis, and Research for Sustainable Technology (CLEAReST), which will serve as a focal point for the scientific advancements required to develop lignin-first processes for biomass conversion.  Formation of CLEAReST is inspired by the global need to find renewable replacements for aromatic petrochemicals to sustainably address energy, climate, and food security needs.  These aromatic compounds are found in everyday products including fuels, plastics, personal care products, and pharmaceuticals.  Lignin, a biopolymer found in all plants, is the only renewable source of aromatic chemicals, but is difficult to effectively utilize because of its complex, heterogeneous structure.  Worldwide, there is growing recognition that utilizing lignin is an essential technological part of reducing the environmental and climate impact of human industrial activity.  By making scientific advances in its core scientific and engineering missions, CLEAReST will lower technological barriers to realizing this goal.  This will be accelerated by cooperating with global lignin science partners and industrial leaders to address the most relevant problems in lignin processing.  

Breakthroughs in science and engineering of lignin will be cultivated by pursuing five parallel, intertwined missions.  First, the fundamental rules of life governing lignin biosynthesis will be uncovered and engineered to create plant feedstocks able to be deconstructed into valuable building blocks without loss of food value.  Second, dedicated analytical tools will be assembled to provide comprehensive characterization of lignin all the way from plant cell to final product.  Third, the science of lignin deconstruction will be advanced to provide efficient ways to convert a given lignin source to the most suitable set of intermediate chemicals.  Fourth, discovery-based applications of lignin-derived products will be advanced by developing structure-property relationships for well-defined lignin molecules.  Finally, the systems thinking and convergence research-driven advances in lignin science of CLEAReST will be used as a platform for recruiting a diverse cohort of students and providing education, outreach, and knowledge transfer to an interdisciplinary scientific workforce.  The Center integrates the first four missions to seek scientific breakthroughs that advance integrated lignin science from its initial biosynthesis in plants to structure-property relationships in upgraded products.  This planning grant will define high-impact engineering science targets within the missions of CLEAReST by bringing together potential collaborators and stakeholders for a series of workshops.  To move towards the goal of broadening the impact and participation of scientists from all backgrounds in the lignin utilization challenge, the planning grant includes activities to strengthen ties with social science researchers to better understand the economic, educational, and social implications of expanding the biorefining concept in rural communities, thus moving towards decentralized processing of lignin as a renewable source of aromatic chemicals, pharmaceutical precursors, and advanced materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In its Bold Goals report from March 2023, the White House calls for reaching net-zero emissions in the United States by 2050, in part through research on “alternative processes to produce chemicals and materials from renewable biomass and intermediate feedstocks by developing low-carbon-intensity product pathways and promoting a circular economy for materials.” This planning grant allowed a team of investigators at the University of Kentucky, Louisiana State University, the University of Puerto Rico Mayagüez, and Washington State University to develop the concept of a Generation-4 Engineering Research Center (Gen-4 ERC) aimed at addressing this challenge by overcoming technological barriers to utilization of the lignin biopolymer from plant biomass as a feedstock for chemicals and materials that are currently derived from petrochemicals.  The goal of this multi-university partnership with industry, national labs, and other stakeholders is to advance lignin as a renewable alternative feedstock to petroleum for bioplastics, detergents, pharmaceuticals, and other chemicals and materials that are used daily in modern life. As a phenolic biopolymer, lignin’s structure, function, and bioactivity make it the kind of sustainable solution that consumers demand and engineers want to provide. 

Through a series of workshops and one-on-one meetings with technology leaders in industry, national labs, and state governments, the key barriers to lignin utilization were identified, a research strategy was outlined, and a team was assembled to conduct the research and development in the Center for Lignin Engineering, Analysis, and Research for Sustainable Technology (CLEAReST).  The vision of CLEAReST is to take a transformative, holistic approach to unlock a lignin-derived innovation ecosystem by coupling plant cell wall pathway engineering with the development of advanced lignin extraction and valorization processes. CLEAReST will promote innovation and economic development through sustainability and stakeholder engagement, and will serve as a focal point for broadening participation through STEM education and workforce development.

Industry articulated three barriers to lignin utilization: (1) the heterogeneity of lignin within and among biomass feedstocks, (2) the complexity of processes to upgrade lignin, and (3) undesirable color and chemical changes associated with process lignins (e.g., from paper pulping). Recent breakthroughs have shown that these problems can be overcome through “lignin-first” processes avoiding condensation of reactive sites generated during processes targeting cellulose. CLEAReST builds on this to accelerate distributed production of aromatic chemicals from regional agriculture by integrating cohorts of engineers and scientists performing convergent research in four research missions spanning the lignin value chain.

Mission 1 characterizes lignin from various regional plant biomass sources to engineer the production in plants of simplified and functionalized lignin amenable to processing. Mission 2 integrates advanced lignin analytical tools with data analytics and multiscale modeling (from molecular simulations to life cycle analysis) to guide engineering decisions. Mission 3 lowers barriers to lignin isolation and deconstruction by developing nontraditional solvents and decarbonized reaction and separation equipment. Mission 4 expands the market for lignin oligomers by investigating lignin-based bioactive materials and ecologically safe bioplastics. Convergence results from using process engineering to link needed / observed lignin structure in plants with stakeholder needs and constraints including properties, function, economics, and life cycle.

CLEAReST is an alliance of land grant universities that advances scientific and engineering discovery at the interface of agriculture and manufacturing, thus increasing the impact of the institutional missions in education, engineering workforce development (EWD) and outreach.  Through this planning grant, CLEAReST developed strategies to recruit, educate, and train diverse engineers and scientists via its technical missions, within an ecosystem that bridges universities, industry, national labs, growers, and the public to achieve long-term societal impact. CLEAReST addresses critical needs to build a diverse and inclusive workforce equipped to drive innovation in sustainable engineering through cohesive EWD and diversity and culture of inclusion (DCI) initiatives that emphasize community building, a sense of belonging, and transferable skills for scientists and engineers. University curriculum development focuses on sustainable engineering and building student research cohorts under a model that scales across institutions. Graduate student training in transferable skills for scientists and engineers complements convergent, industry-driven research projects on sustainable innovations. CLEAReST will create pathways to and through STEM majors for students traditionally underrepresented in engineering by implementing a virtual bridge to engineering program, a cohort model for undergraduate research, and micro-grants that expand opportunities for CLEAReST to partner with regional minority-serving institutions.  To provide a robust innovation ecosystem, CLEAReST will invite industry and practitioner participation at all stages, from IP generation and start-up companies based on ERC research to an industry-university consortium to inform technological relevance.

The capstone outcome of this planning grant was the development and submission of a full Gen-4 ERC proposal at the end of the planning grant period, after the proposal team successfully passed the preliminary proposal stage.
